==Early life and education==
==Early life and education==
Joel Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]], in 1946.<ref name="nobel" /> He was born into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, Salomon Mok,<ref name=":4" /> a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old.<ref name=":0" /> He immigrated to [[Israel]] as a child with his mother, Gunda Mok (née Jakobs),<ref name=":4" /> and grew up in [[Haifa]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr wins Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences |url=https://news.northwestern.edu/stories/2025/10/joel-mokyr-wins-nobel-prize-in-economics |access-date=14 October 2025 |website=news.northwestern.edu |language=en}}</ref> He then received an [[Master of Philosophy|M.Phil.]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972,<ref name=":6" /> and a Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1974.<ref name=":6" /> His dissertation was titled, ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800–1850''.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Mokyr |first=Joel |url=https://search.library.yale.edu/catalog/9932132453408651?block=Books |title=Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800–1850 |date=1974}}</ref>
Joel Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]], Netherlands, in 1946.<ref name="nobel" /> He was born into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father Salomon Mok,<ref name=":4" /> a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old.<ref name=":0" /> He immigrated to [[Israel]] as a child with his mother Gunda Mok (née Jakobs),<ref name=":4" /> and grew up in [[Haifa]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr wins Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences |url=https://news.northwestern.edu/stories/2025/10/joel-mokyr-wins-nobel-prize-in-economics |access-date=14 October 2025 |website=news.northwestern.edu |language=en}}</ref> He then received an [[Master of Philosophy|M.Phil.]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972, and a Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1974.<ref name=":6" /> His dissertation was titled ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800–1850''.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Mokyr |first=Joel |url=https://search.library.yale.edu/catalog/9932132453408651?block=Books |title=Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800–1850 |date=1974}}</ref>


==Career==
==Career==
Mokyr was an acting instructor at [[Yale University]] between 1972 and 1973,<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last2=Boiskin |first=Jaeha | last=Jang |first2=Asher |date=14 October 2025 |title=Yale graduate wins economics Nobel Prize for studying economic growth |url=https://yaledailynews.com/blog/2025/10/14/yale-graduate-wins-economics-nobel-prize-for-studying-economic-growth/ |access-date=14 October 2025 |website=Yale Daily News |language=en}}</ref> and became an [[assistant professor]] at [[Northwestern University]] in 1974, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=":2" />
Mokyr was an acting instructor at [[Yale University]] between 1972 and 1973, and became an [[assistant professor]] at [[Northwestern University]] in 1974, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=Jang |first=Jaeha |last2=Boiskin |first2=Asher |date=14 October 2025 |title=Yale graduate wins economics Nobel Prize for studying economic growth |url=https://yaledailynews.com/blog/2025/10/14/yale-graduate-wins-economics-nobel-prize-for-studying-economic-growth/ |access-date=14 October 2025 |website=Yale Daily News |language=en}}</ref>


He has been the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Economic History of the Western World (a book series published by [[Princeton University Press]]), and was a co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Economic History]]''.<ref name=":6" /> He was President of the [[Economic History Association]] from 2002 to 2003.<ref name="PastPresident">{{cite web | title=EHA Society of Fellows – EH.net | website=EH.net – PRESERVING THE PAST, ILLUMINATING THE PRESENT, SHAPING THE FUTURE | url=https://eh.net/eha-society-of-fellows/ | access-date=13 October 2025}}</ref>
He has been the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Economic History of the Western World (a book series published by [[Princeton University Press]]), and was a co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Economic History]]''.<ref name=":6" /> He was the President of the [[Economic History Association]] from 2002 to 2003.<ref name="PastPresident">{{cite web | title=EHA Society of Fellows – EH.net | website=EH.net – PRESERVING THE PAST, ILLUMINATING THE PRESENT, SHAPING THE FUTURE | url=https://eh.net/eha-society-of-fellows/ | access-date=13 October 2025}}</ref>


==''A Culture of Growth''==
==''A Culture of Growth''==
Mokyr presents his explanations for the [[Industrial Revolution]] in the 2016 book ''A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy''. The book has received positive reviews. [[Deirdre McCloskey]] described it as a "brilliant book... It’s long, but consistently interesting, even witty. It sustains interest right down to page 337... The book is not beach reading. But you will finish it impressively learned about how we got to where we are in the modern world."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism|title=Economic history: ideas that built the world|website=www.prospectmagazine.co.uk|access-date=11 March 2017|archive-date=8 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210508081836/https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism|url-status=dead}}</ref> In her review, McCloskey furthermore lauded Mokyr as a "[[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Nobel]]-worthy economic scientist".<ref name=":1"/>
Mokyr presents his explanations for the [[Industrial Revolution]] in the 2016 book ''A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy''. The book has received positive reviews. [[Deirdre McCloskey]] described it as a "brilliant book... It's long, but consistently interesting, even witty. It sustains interest right down to page 337... The book is not beach reading. But you will finish it impressively learned about how we got to where we are in the modern world." In her review, McCloskey furthermore lauded Mokyr as a "[[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Nobel]]-worthy economic scientist".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |title=Economic history: ideas that built the world |url=http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210508081836/https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism |archive-date=8 May 2021 |access-date=11 March 2017 |website=www.prospectmagazine.co.uk}}</ref>


In a review published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', [[J. Bradford DeLong|Brad DeLong]] found that while he favored other explanations for the Industrial Revolution, "I would not be greatly surprised if I were wrong, and Mokyr's brief...turned out to be the most broadly correct analysis...''A Culture of Growth'' is certainly making me rethink."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=DeLong|first=Brad|date=27 October 2016|title=Economic history: The roots of growth |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |language=en |volume=538 |issue=7626|pages=456–57|doi=10.1038/538456a|bibcode=2016Natur.538..456D|issn=0028-0836|doi-access=free}}</ref>
In a review published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', [[J. Bradford DeLong|Brad DeLong]] found that while he favored other explanations for the Industrial Revolution, "I would not be greatly surprised if I were wrong, and Mokyr's brief...turned out to be the most broadly correct analysis...''A Culture of Growth'' is certainly making me rethink."<ref>{{Cite journal |last=DeLong |first=Brad |author-link=James Bradford DeLong |date=27 October 2016 |title=Economic history: The roots of growth |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |language=en |volume=538 |issue=7626 |pages=456–57 |bibcode=2016Natur.538..456D |doi=10.1038/538456a |issn=0028-0836 |doi-access=free}}</ref>


Cambridge economic historian [[Victoria Bateman]] wrote, "In pointing to growth-boosting factors that go beyond either the state or the market, Mokyr's book is very welcome. It could also feed into discussions about the scientific community post-[[Brexit]]. By reviving the focus on culture it will, however, prove controversial, particularly among economists."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/books/review-a-culture-of-growth-joel-mokyr-princeton-university-press|title=A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy, by Joel Mokyr|date=6 October 2016|work=Times Higher Education|access-date=11 March 2017}}</ref> An article in ''[[The Economist]]'' pointed out that a fine definitional distinction had to be considered between “culture as ideas, socially learned” and “culture as inheritance transmitted genetically”.<ref>{{Cite December 2016|work=Foreign Affairs|access-date=11 March 2017|issn=0015-7120}}</ref> [[The Independent|''The Independent'']],<ref>{{Cite == Honours and awards ==
== Honours and awards ==
Mokyr was elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1996, and was elected a [[List of fellows of the Econometric Society|Fellow]] of the [[Econometric Society]] in 2011.<ref>{{Cite ==Early life and education==
==Early life and education==
Joel Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]], in 1946.<ref name="nobel" /> He was born into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, Salomon Mok,<ref name=":4" /> a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old.<ref name=":0" /> He immigrated to [[Israel]] as a child with his mother, Gunda Mok (née Jakobs),<ref name=":4" /> and grew up in [[Haifa]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr wins Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences |url=https://news.northwestern.edu/stories/2025/10/joel-mokyr-wins-nobel-prize-in-economics |access-date=2025-10-14 |website=news.northwestern.edu |language=en}}</ref> He then received an [[Master of Philosophy|M.Phil.]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972,<ref name=":6" /> and a Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1974.<ref name=":6" /> His dissertation was titled, ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800-1850''.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Mokyr |first=Joel |url=https://search.library.yale.edu/catalog/9932132453408651?block=Books |title=Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800-1850 |date=1974}}</ref>
Joel Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]], in 1946.<ref name="nobel" /> He was born into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, Salomon Mok,<ref name=":4" /> a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old.<ref name=":0" /> He immigrated to [[Israel]] as a child with his mother, Gunda Mok (née Jakobs),<ref name=":4" /> and grew up in [[Haifa]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr wins Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences |url=https://news.northwestern.edu/stories/2025/10/joel-mokyr-wins-nobel-prize-in-economics |access-date=14 October 2025 |website=news.northwestern.edu |language=en}}</ref> He then received an [[Master of Philosophy|M.Phil.]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972,<ref name=":6" /> and a Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1974.<ref name=":6" /> His dissertation was titled, ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800–1850''.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Mokyr |first=Joel |url=https://search.library.yale.edu/catalog/9932132453408651?block=Books |title=Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800–1850 |date=1974}}</ref>


==Career==
==Career==
Mokyr was an acting instructor at [[Yale University]] between 1972 and 1973,<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last2=Boiskin |first=Jaeha | last=Jang |first2=Asher |date=2025-10-14 |title=Yale graduate wins economics Nobel Prize for studying economic growth |url=https://yaledailynews.com/blog/2025/10/14/yale-graduate-wins-economics-nobel-prize-for-studying-economic-growth/ |access-date=2025-10-14 |website=Yale Daily News |language=en}}</ref> and became an [[assistant professor]] at [[Northwestern University]] in 1974, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=":2" />
Mokyr was an acting instructor at [[Yale University]] between 1972 and 1973,<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last2=Boiskin |first=Jaeha | last=Jang |first2=Asher |date=14 October 2025 |title=Yale graduate wins economics Nobel Prize for studying economic growth |url=https://yaledailynews.com/blog/2025/10/14/yale-graduate-wins-economics-nobel-prize-for-studying-economic-growth/ |access-date=14 October 2025 |website=Yale Daily News |language=en}}</ref> and became an [[assistant professor]] at [[Northwestern University]] in 1974, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=":2" />


He has been the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Economic History of the Western World (a book series published by [[Princeton University Press]]), and was a co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Economic History]]''.<ref name=":6" /> He was President of the [[Economic History Association]] from 2002 to 2003.<ref name="PastPresident">{{cite web | title=EHA Society of Fellows – EH.net | website=EH.net – PRESERVING THE PAST, ILLUMINATING THE PRESENT, SHAPING THE FUTURE | url=https://eh.net/eha-society-of-fellows/ | access-date=2025-10-13}}</ref>
He has been the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Economic History of the Western World (a book series published by [[Princeton University Press]]), and was a co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Economic History]]''.<ref name=":6" /> He was President of the [[Economic History Association]] from 2002 to 2003.<ref name="PastPresident">{{cite web | title=EHA Society of Fellows – EH.net | website=EH.net – PRESERVING THE PAST, ILLUMINATING THE PRESENT, SHAPING THE FUTURE | url=https://eh.net/eha-society-of-fellows/ | access-date=13 October 2025}}</ref>

⚫
==''A Culture of Growth''==
==Research==
⚫
Mokyr presents his explanations for the [[Industrial Revolution]] in the 2016 book ''A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy''. The book has received positive reviews. [[Deirdre McCloskey]] described it as a "brilliant book... It’s long, but consistently interesting, even witty. It sustains interest right down to page 337... The book is not beach reading. But you will finish it impressively learned about how we got to where we are in the modern world."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism|title=Economic history: ideas that built the world|website=www.prospectmagazine.co.uk|access-date=11 March 2017|archive-date=8 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210508081836/https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism|url-status=dead}}</ref> In her review, McCloskey furthermore lauded Mokyr as a "[[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Nobel]]-worthy economic scientist".<ref name=":1"/>
===Industrial Revolution===
{{Primary sources|section|date=October 2025}}
Mokyr posits that the [[Industrial Revolution]] was the result of culture and institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|date=1 June 2005|title=The Intellectual Origins of Modern Economic Growth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/the-intellectual-origins-of-modern-economic-growth/138F07525A5105E29E7113705D393C51|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=65|issue=2|pages=285–351|doi=10.1017/S0022050705000112|s2cid=54225284 |issn=1471-6372|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He argues that the root of modernity is in "the emergence of a belief in the usefulness of progress", and that "it was a turning point when intellectuals started to conceive of knowledge as cumulative".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/11/progress-isnt-natural-mokyr/507740|title=Progress Isn't Natural|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref>

Mokyr furthermore argues that political fragmentation (the presence of a large number of European states) made it possible for heterodox ideas to thrive, as entrepreneurs, innovators, ideologues, and heretics could easily flee to a neighbouring state in the event that the one state would try to suppress their ideas and activities. This is what set Europe apart from the technologically advanced, large unitary empires such as China and India. China had [[movable type]], and India had similar levels of scientific and technological achievement as Europe in 1700, yet the Industrial Revolution would occur in Europe, not China or India. In Europe, political fragmentation was coupled with an "integrated market for ideas" where Europe's intellectuals used the lingua franca of [[Latin]], had a shared intellectual basis in Europe's classical heritage and the pan-European institution of the [[Republic of Letters]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/10835.html|title=Mokyr, J.: A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy |isbn=9780691180960 |access-date=9 March 2017|last1=Mokyr |first1=Joel |year=2018 |publisher=Princeton University Press }}</ref>

⚫
===''A Culture of Growth''===
⚫
Mokyr presents his explanations for the Industrial Revolution in the 2016 book ''A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy''. The book has received positive reviews. [[Deirdre McCloskey]] described it as a "brilliant book... It’s long, but consistently interesting, even witty. It sustains interest right down to page 337... The book is not beach reading. But you will finish it impressively learned about how we got to where we are in the modern world."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism|title=Economic history: ideas that built the world|website=www.prospectmagazine.co.uk|access-date=11 March 2017|archive-date=8 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210508081836/https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/arts-and-books/ideas-that-built-the-world-joel-mokyr-liberalism|url-status=dead}}</ref> In her review, McCloskey furthermore lauded Mokyr as a "[[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Nobel]]-worthy economic scientist".<ref name=":1"/>


In a review published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', [[J. Bradford DeLong|Brad DeLong]] found that while he favored other explanations for the Industrial Revolution, "I would not be greatly surprised if I were wrong, and Mokyr's brief...turned out to be the most broadly correct analysis...''A Culture of Growth'' is certainly making me rethink."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=DeLong|first=Brad|date=27 October 2016|title=Economic history: The roots of growth |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |language=en |volume=538 |issue=7626|pages=456–57|doi=10.1038/538456a|bibcode=2016Natur.538..456D|issn=0028-0836|doi-access=free}}</ref>
In a review published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', [[J. Bradford DeLong|Brad DeLong]] found that while he favored other explanations for the Industrial Revolution, "I would not be greatly surprised if I were wrong, and Mokyr's brief...turned out to be the most broadly correct analysis...''A Culture of Growth'' is certainly making me rethink."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=DeLong|first=Brad|date=27 October 2016|title=Economic history: The roots of growth |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |language=en |volume=538 |issue=7626|pages=456–57|doi=10.1038/538456a|bibcode=2016Natur.538..456D|issn=0028-0836|doi-access=free}}</ref>

===Resistance to new technologies===
{{Primary sources|section|date=October 2025}}
Mokyr outlined three reasons why societies resist new technologies:
* Incumbents who fear a threat to their power and [[economic rent]]s
* Concern about broader social and political repercussions ("unintended ripple effects")
* [[Risk aversion|Risk]] and [[loss aversion]]: new technologies often have "unanticipated and unknowable consequences"

"These three motives often merge and create powerful forces that use political power and persuasion to thwart innovations. As a result, technological progress does not follow a linear and neat trajectory. It is, as social constructionists have been trying to tell us for decades, a profoundly political process."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eh.net/book_reviews/innovation-and-its-enemies-why-people-resist-new-technologies|title=Innovation and Its Enemies: Why People Resist New Technologies|website=eh.net|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>

Joel Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]], in 1946.<ref name="nobel" /> He was born into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, Salomon Mok,<ref name=":4" /> a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old.<ref name=":0" /> He immigrated to [[Israel]] as a child with his mother, Gunda Mok (née Jakobs),<ref name=":4" /> and grew up in [[Haifa]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr wins Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences |url=https://news.northwestern.edu/stories/2025/10/joel-mokyr-wins-nobel-prize-in-economics |access-date=2025-10-14 |website=news.northwestern.edu |language=en}}</ref> He received an [[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972,<ref name=":6" /> and a PhD in economics from Yale in 1974,<ref name=":6" /> writing a dissertation titled ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800-1850''.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Mokyr |first=Joel |url=https://search.library.yale.edu/catalog/9932132453408651?block=Books |title=Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800-1850 |date=1974}}</ref>

===Industrial Revolution===
===Industrial Revolution===
⚫
{{Primary sources|section|date=October 2025}}
Mokyr posits that the [[Industrial Revolution]] was the result of culture and institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|date=1 June 2005|title=The Intellectual Origins of Modern Economic Growth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/the-intellectual-origins-of-modern-economic-growth/138F07525A5105E29E7113705D393C51|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=65|issue=2|pages=285–351|doi=10.1017/S0022050705000112|s2cid=54225284 |issn=1471-6372|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He argues that the root of modernity is in "the emergence of a belief in the usefulness of progress", and that "it was a turning point when intellectuals started to conceive of knowledge as cumulative".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/11/progress-isnt-natural-mokyr/507740|title=Progress Isn't Natural|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref>
Mokyr posits that the [[Industrial Revolution]] was the result of culture and institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|date=1 June 2005|title=The Intellectual Origins of Modern Economic Growth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/the-intellectual-origins-of-modern-economic-growth/138F07525A5105E29E7113705D393C51|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=65|issue=2|pages=285–351|doi=10.1017/S0022050705000112|s2cid=54225284 |issn=1471-6372|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He argues that the root of modernity is in "the emergence of a belief in the usefulness of progress", and that "it was a turning point when intellectuals started to conceive of knowledge as cumulative".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/11/progress-isnt-natural-mokyr/507740|title=Progress Isn't Natural|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref>


Mokyr furthermore argues that political fragmentation (the presence of a large number of European states) made it possible for heterodox ideas to thrive, as entrepreneurs, innovators, ideologues, and heretics could easily flee to a neighbouring state in the event that the one state would try to suppress their ideas and activities. This is what set Europe apart from the technologically advanced, large unitary empires such as China and India. China had [[movable type]], and India had similar levels of scientific and technological achievement as Europe in 1700, yet the Industrial Revolution would occur in Europe, not China or India. In Europe, political fragmentation was coupled with an "integrated market for ideas" where Europe's intellectuals used the lingua franca of [[Latin]], had a shared intellectual basis in Europe's classical heritage and the pan-European institution of the [[Republic of Letters]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/10835.html|title=Mokyr, J.: A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy |isbn=9780691180960 |access-date=9 March 2017|last1=Mokyr |first1=Joel |year=2018 |publisher=Princeton University Press }}</ref>

Mokyr presents his explanations for the Industrial Revolution in the 2016 book ''A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy''. The book has received positive reviews. '''Joel Mokyr''' ({{langx|he|יואל מוקיר}}; born 26 July 1946<ref>{{cite web|title=Joel Mokyr|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economic-sciences/2025/mokyr/facts/|website=Nobel Foundation}}</ref>) is a Dutch-born American-Israeli [[economic historian]] who has been a professor of economics and history and the [[Robert H. Strotz|{{Nobr|Robert H. Strotz}}]] Professor of Arts and Sciences at [[Northwestern University]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr |url=https://www.beloit.edu/live/profiles/544-joel-mokyr |access-date=2025-10-13 |website=Beloit College |language=en}}</ref> He has also been the Sackler Professorial Fellow at the Eitan Berglas School of Economics at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref name=":3" /> He was awarded half a share of the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] in 2025 "for having identified the prerequisites for sustained growth through technological progress."<ref name="nobel">{{Cite web |work=The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences |date=13 October 2025 |title=The Prize in Economic Sciences 2025 |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/uploads/2025/10/press-economicsciencesprize2025.pdf }}</ref>
'''Joel Michael Mokyr'''<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |title=Joel Michael Mokyr |url=https://www.dutchjewry.org/genealogy/mok/39.shtml |access-date=2025-10-14 |website=www.dutchjewry.org}}</ref> ({{langx|he|יואל מוקיר}}; born 26 July 1946<ref>{{cite web|title=Joel Mokyr|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economic-sciences/2025/mokyr/facts/|website=Nobel Foundation}}</ref>) is a Dutch-born American-Israeli [[economic historian]] who has been a professor of economics and history and the [[Robert H. Strotz|{{Nobr|Robert H. Strotz}}]] Professor of Arts and Sciences at [[Northwestern University]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr |url=https://www.beloit.edu/live/profiles/544-joel-mokyr |access-date=2025-10-13 |website=Beloit College |language=en}}</ref> He has also been the Sackler Professorial Fellow at the Eitan Berglas School of Economics at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref name=":3" /> He was awarded half a share of the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] in 2025 "for having identified the prerequisites for sustained growth through technological progress."<ref name="nobel">{{Cite web |work=The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences |date=13 October 2025 |title=The Prize in Economic Sciences 2025 |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/uploads/2025/10/press-economicsciencesprize2025.pdf }}</ref>


==Early life and education==
==Early life and education==
Joel Mokyr was born '''Joel Michael Mok'''<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |title=Joel Michael Mokyr |url=https://www.dutchjewry.org/genealogy/mok/39.shtml |access-date=2025-10-14 |website=www.dutchjewry.org}}</ref> in [[Leiden]] in 1946.<ref name="nobel" /> He was born into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, Salomon Mok,<ref name=":4" /> a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old, and so he was raised by his mother, Gunda Mok (née Jakobs)<ref name=":4" /> in [[Haifa]], Israel.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web | url=https://bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com/sites.northwestern.edu/dist/3/1222/files/2021/08/Mokyr-2021-CV.pdf | title=CURRICULUM VITAE - Joel Mokyr | website=bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr wins Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences |url=https://news.northwestern.edu/stories/2025/10/joel-mokyr-wins-nobel-prize-in-economics |access-date=2025-10-14 |website=news.northwestern.edu |language=en}}</ref> He received an [[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972, and a PhD in economics from Yale in 1974, writing a dissertation titled ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the [[Low Countries]], 1800-1850'' under the supervision of [[William N. Parker]], [[Lloyd G. Reynolds]], and [[Fei–Ranis model of economic growth|John C.H. Fei]].<ref name="cv">{{cite web|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=https://sites.northwestern.edu/jmokyr/files/2016/06/Mokyr-CV-296d1iv.pdf|website=Northwestern University|access-date=27 January 2018|date=June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Mokyr |first=Joel |url=https://search.library.yale.edu/catalog/9932132453408651?block=Books |title=Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the Low Countries, 1800-1850 |date=1974}}</ref>

==Career==
==Career==
Mokyr was an acting instructor at [[Yale University]] between 1972 and 1973, and became an [[assistant professor]] at [[Northwestern University]] in 1974, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=":0"/> has been the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Economic History of the Western World (a book series published by [[Princeton University Press]]) since 1993, and was a co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Economic History]]'' from 1994 to 1998.<ref name=":2" /> He was President of the [[Economic History Association]] from 2002 to 2003.<ref name=":2" /><ref name="PastPresident">{{cite web | title=EHA Society of Fellows – EH.net | website=EH.net – PRESERVING THE PAST, ILLUMINATING THE PRESENT, SHAPING THE FUTURE | url=https://eh.net/eha-society-of-fellows/ | access-date=2025-10-13}}</ref>

Mokyr was an acting instructor at [[Yale University]] between 1972 and 1973, and became an [[assistant professor]] at [[Northwestern University]] in 1974, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=":0"/> has been the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Economic History of the Western World (a book series published by [[Princeton University Press]]) since 1993, and was a co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Economic History]]'' from 1994 to 1998.<ref name=":2" /> He was President of the [[Economic History Association]] from 2002 to 2003.<ref name=":2" /><ref name="PastPresident">{{cite web | title=EHA Society of Fellows – EH.net | website=EH.net – PRESERVING THE PAST, ILLUMINATING THE PRESENT, SHAPING THE FUTURE | url=https://eh.net/eha-society-of-fellows/ | access-date=2025-10-13}}</ref>


==Research==
==Research==
Line 66: Line 66:
Mokyr posits that the [[Industrial Revolution]] was the result of culture and institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|date=1 June 2005|title=The Intellectual Origins of Modern Economic Growth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/the-intellectual-origins-of-modern-economic-growth/138F07525A5105E29E7113705D393C51|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=65|issue=2|pages=285–351|doi=10.1017/S0022050705000112|s2cid=54225284 |issn=1471-6372|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He argues that the root of modernity is in "the emergence of a belief in the usefulness of progress", and that "it was a turning point when intellectuals started to conceive of knowledge as cumulative".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/11/progress-isnt-natural-mokyr/507740|title=Progress Isn't Natural|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref>
Mokyr posits that the [[Industrial Revolution]] was the result of culture and institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|date=1 June 2005|title=The Intellectual Origins of Modern Economic Growth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/the-intellectual-origins-of-modern-economic-growth/138F07525A5105E29E7113705D393C51|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=65|issue=2|pages=285–351|doi=10.1017/S0022050705000112|s2cid=54225284 |issn=1471-6372|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He argues that the root of modernity is in "the emergence of a belief in the usefulness of progress", and that "it was a turning point when intellectuals started to conceive of knowledge as cumulative".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/11/progress-isnt-natural-mokyr/507740|title=Progress Isn't Natural|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref>


Mokyr furthermore argues that political fragmentation (the presence of a large number of European states) made it possible for heterodox ideas to thrive, as entrepreneurs, innovators, ideologues, and heretics could easily flee to a neighbouring state in the event that the one state would try to suppress their ideas and activities. This is what set Europe apart from the technologically advanced, large unitary empires such as China and India. China had both a [[printing press]] and [[movable type]], and India had similar levels of scientific and technological achievement as Europe in 1700, yet the Industrial Revolution would occur in Europe, not China or India. In Europe, political fragmentation was coupled with an "integrated market for ideas" where Europe's intellectuals used the lingua franca of [[Latin]], had a shared intellectual basis in Europe's classical heritage and the pan-European institution of the [[Republic of Letters]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/10835.html|title=Mokyr, J.: A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy |isbn=9780691180960 |access-date=9 March 2017|last1=Mokyr |first1=Joel |year=2018 |publisher=Princeton University Press }}</ref>

This is what set Europe apart from the technologically advanced, large unitary empires such as China and India. China had [[movable type]], and India had similar levels of scientific and technological achievement as Europe in 1700, yet the Industrial Revolution would occur in Europe, not China or India. '''Joel Mokyr''' (born 26 July 1946<ref>{{cite web|title=Joel Mokyr|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economic-sciences/2025/mokyr/facts/|website=Nobel Foundation}}</ref>) is a Dutch-born American-Israeli{{Citation needed|date=October 2025}} [[economic historian]] who has been a professor of economics and history and the [[Robert H. Strotz]] Professor of Arts and Sciences at [[Northwestern University]] since 1994.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web | url=https://bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com/sites.northwestern.edu/dist/3/1222/files/2021/08/Mokyr-2021-CV.pdf | title=CURRICULUM VITAE - Joel Mokyr | website=bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com}}</ref>{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}} Since 2001, he has also been the Sackler Professorial Fellow at the Eitan Berglas School of Economics at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref name=":2" />{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}} He was awarded half a share of the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] in 2025 "for having identified the prerequisites for sustained growth through technological progress."<ref name="nobel">{{Cite web |work=The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences |date=13 October 2025 |title=The Prize in Economic Sciences 2025 |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/uploads/2025/10/press-economicsciencesprize2025.pdf |url-status=live}}</ref>
'''Joel Mokyr''' ({{langx|he|יואל מוקיר}}; born 26 July 1946<ref>{{cite web|title=Joel Mokyr|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economic-sciences/2025/mokyr/facts/|website=Nobel Foundation}}</ref>) is a Dutch-born American-Israeli{{Citation needed|date=October 2025}} [[economic historian]] who has been a professor of economics and history and the [[Robert H. Strotz]] Professor of Arts and Sciences at [[Northwestern University]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |title=Joel Mokyr |url=https://www.beloit.edu/live/profiles/544-joel-mokyr |access-date=2025-10-13 |website=Beloit College |language=en}}</ref> He has also been the Sackler Professorial Fellow at the Eitan Berglas School of Economics at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref name=":3" /> He was awarded half a share of the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] in 2025 "for having identified the prerequisites for sustained growth through technological progress."<ref name="nobel">{{Cite web |work=The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences |date=13 October 2025 |title=The Prize in Economic Sciences 2025 |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/uploads/2025/10/press-economicsciencesprize2025.pdf |url-status=live}}</ref>


==Early life and education==
==Early life and education==
Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]] in 1946.<ref name="nobel" /> He was born into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old, and so he was raised by his mother in [[Haifa]], Israel.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":2" />{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}} He received an [[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972, and a PhD in economics from Yale in 1974, writing a dissertation titled ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the [[Low Countries]], 1800-1850'' under the supervision of [[William N. Parker]], [[Lloyd G. Reynolds]], and [[Fei–Ranis model of economic growth|John C.H. Fei]].<ref name="cv">{{cite web|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=https://sites.northwestern.edu/jmokyr/files/2016/06/Mokyr-CV-296d1iv.pdf|website=Northwestern University|access-date=27 January 2018|date=June 2016}}</ref>{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}}

Parker]], [[Lloyd G. Reynolds]], and [[Fei–Ranis model of economic growth|John C.H. ==Early life and education==
==Early life and education==
Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]], into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old, and so he was raised by his mother in [[Haifa]], Israel.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":2" />{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}} He received an [[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972, and a PhD in economics from Yale in 1974, writing a dissertation titled ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the [[Low Countries]], 1800-1850'' under the supervision of [[William N. Parker]], [[Lloyd G. Reynolds]], and [[Fei–Ranis model of economic growth|John C.H. Fei]].<ref name="cv">{{cite web|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=https://sites.northwestern.edu/jmokyr/files/2016/06/Mokyr-CV-296d1iv.pdf|website=Northwestern University|access-date=27 January 2018|date=June 2016}}</ref>{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}}

Strotz]] Professor of Arts and Sciences at [[Northwestern University]] since 1994.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web | url=https://bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com/sites.northwestern.edu/dist/3/1222/files/2021/08/Mokyr-2021-CV.pdf | title=CURRICULUM VITAE - Joel Mokyr | website=bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com}}</ref> Since 2001, he has also been the Sackler Professorial Fellow at the Eitan Berglas School of Economics at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref name=":2" />
'''Joel Mokyr''' is a Dutch-born American-Israeli [[economic historian]] who has been a professor of economics and history and the [[Robert H. Strotz]] Professor of Arts and Sciences at [[Northwestern University]] since 1994.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web | url=https://bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com/sites.northwestern.edu/dist/3/1222/files/2021/08/Mokyr-2021-CV.pdf | title=CURRICULUM VITAE - Joel Mokyr | website=bpb-us-e1.wpmucdn.com}}</ref>{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}} Since 2001, he has also been the Sackler Professorial Fellow at the Eitan Berglas School of Economics at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref name=":2" />{{Independent source inline|date=October 2025}} He was awarded the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] in 2025.{{cn}}


==Early life and education==
==Early life and education==
Mokyr was born in [[Leiden]] in 1946, into a family of [[History of the Jews in the Netherlands|Dutch Jews]] who had survived the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=":0" /> His father, a civil servant, died of cancer when Mokyr was one year old, and so he was raised by his mother in [[Haifa]], Israel.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/economists-duel-over-idea-that-technology-will-save-the-world-1402886301|title=Economists Debate: Has All the Important Stuff Already Been Invented?|last=Aeppel|first=Timothy|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in economics and history from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in 1968.<ref name=":2" /> He received an [[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]] in economics from [[Yale University]] in 1972, and a PhD in economics from Yale in 1974, writing a dissertation titled ''Industrial Growth and Stagnation in the [[Low Countries]], 1800-1850'' under the supervision of [[William N. Parker]], [[Lloyd G. Reynolds]], and [[Fei–Ranis model of economic growth|John C.H. Fei]].<ref name="cv">{{cite web|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=https://sites.northwestern.edu/jmokyr/files/2016/06/Mokyr-CV-296d1iv.pdf|website=Northwestern University|access-date=27 January 2018|date=June 2016}}</ref>

==Career==
==Career==
Mokyr was an acting instructor at [[Yale University]] between 1972 and 1973, and became an [[assistant professor]] at [[Northwestern University]] in 1974, where he has remained ever since.<ref name=":0"/> Since then, he has chair or co-chaired over 50 doctoral student theses.<ref name="economics.northwestern.edu">{{cite web |url=https://economics.northwestern.edu/people/directory/mokyr-2021-cv.pdf |title=Curriculum vitae |website=economics.northwestern.edu |access-date=31 August 2021 |date=August 2021}}</ref> He has been the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Economic History of the Western World (a book series published by [[Princeton University Press]]) since 1993, and was a co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Economic History]]'' from 1994 to 1998.<ref name=":2" /> He was President of the [[Economic History Association]] from 2002 to 2003.<ref name=":2" />

⚫
Mokyr was elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1996, and was elected a [[List of fellows of the Econometric Society|Fellow]] of the [[Econometric Society]] in 2011.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Member Directory {{!}} American Academy of Arts and Sciences |url=https://www.amacad.org/directory?field_class_section=21&field_class_section_1=36&field_deceased=1&sort_bef_combine=field_election_year_ASC&page=2 |access-date=2024-01-23 |website=www.amacad.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Current Fellows |url=http://www.econometricsociety.org/society/organization-and-governance/fellows/current |access-date=2024-01-23 |website=www.econometricsociety.org |language=en}}</ref> He was elected a foreign member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2001, whose biennial [[Heineken Prizes|Heineken Award]] for History he received in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.knaw.nl/en/members/foreign-members/5204| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213195608/https://www.knaw.nl/en/members/foreign-members/5204|title=Joël Mokyr|publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences|archive-date=13 February 2016|access-date=13 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.knaw.nl/en/awards/laureates/heinekenprize-history/joel-mokyr-1946-verenigde-staten |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200722154153/https://www.knaw.nl/en/awards/laureates/heinekenprize-history/joel-mokyr-1946-verenigde-staten |title=Joel Mokyr (1946), USA |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |archive-date=22 July 2020}}</ref> He won the 2015 [[Balzan Prize|Balzan International Prize]] for economic history.<ref name="nwbio">{{cite web|title=Joel Mokyr|url=http://www.economics.northwestern.edu/people/directory/joel-mokyr.html|website=Northwestern University|access-date=27 January 2018}}</ref>

===Industrial Revolution===
Mokyr posits that the [[Industrial Revolution]] was the result of culture and institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|date=1 June 2005|title=The Intellectual Origins of Modern Economic Growth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/the-intellectual-origins-of-modern-economic-growth/138F07525A5105E29E7113705D393C51|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=65|issue=2|pages=285–351|doi=10.1017/S0022050705000112|doi-broken-date=1 November 2024 |s2cid=54225284 |issn=1471-6372|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He argues that the root of modernity is in "the emergence of a belief in the usefulness of progress", and that "it was a turning point when intellectuals started to conceive of knowledge as cumulative".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/11/progress-isnt-natural-mokyr/507740|title=Progress Isn't Natural|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref>
Mokyr posits that the [[Industrial Revolution]] was the result of culture and institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|date=1 June 2005|title=The Intellectual Origins of Modern Economic Growth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/the-intellectual-origins-of-modern-economic-growth/138F07525A5105E29E7113705D393C51|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=65|issue=2|pages=285–351|doi=10.1017/S0022050705000112|s2cid=54225284 |issn=1471-6372|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He argues that the root of modernity is in "the emergence of a belief in the usefulness of progress", and that "it was a turning point when intellectuals started to conceive of knowledge as cumulative".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/11/progress-isnt-natural-mokyr/507740|title=Progress Isn't Natural|last=Mokyr|first=Joel|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref>


Mokyr furthermore argues that political fragmentation (the presence of a large number of European states) made it possible for heterodox ideas to thrive, as entrepreneurs, innovators, ideologues, and heretics could easily flee to a neighbouring state in the event that the one state would try to suppress their ideas and activities. This is what set Europe apart from the technologically advanced, large unitary empires such as China and India. China had both a [[printing press]] and [[movable type]], and India had similar levels of scientific and technological achievement as Europe in 1700, yet the Industrial Revolution would occur in Europe, not China or India. In Europe, political fragmentation was coupled with an "integrated market for ideas" where Europe's intellectuals used the lingua franca of [[Latin]], had a shared intellectual basis in Europe's classical heritage and the pan-European institution of the [[Republic of Letters]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/10835.html|title=Mokyr, J.: A Culture of Growth: The Origins of the Modern Economy |isbn=9780691180960 |access-date=9 March 2017|last1=Mokyr |first1=Joel |year=2018 |publisher=Princeton University Press }}</ref>
